tossups.question: Description Acceptable. In one film that employs this narrative technique, a group of people miscount the bullets left in a gun and shoot down a crystal chandelier. In that movie, a butler who says “Communism was just a red herring” is killed by an FBI agent. Another film with this property shows the title character winning at roulette to get 100,000 marks so that Ronnie will spare her boyfriend Manni. In a novel that uses this narrative device, the narrator turns back his watch 15 minutes and (*) tosses a coin before relating how Charles Smithson realizes the disgraced Sarah Woodruff was a virgin and finds her living with Dante Gabriel Rossetti. Cue cards saying “That’s what could have happened, but how about this?” end Clue: The Movie, which has this feature. For 10 points, name this defining characteristic of the conclusions of Run, Lola, Run and The French Lieutenant’s Woman.
tossups.answer: having multiple endings [accept alternate endings, different endings, etc.]
tossups.answer_formatted: having multiple endings [accept alternate endings, different endings, etc.]

tossups.question: Overdose of a drug that inhibits this protein is treated using fab fragments specific to it. A protein of the FXYD family associates with this protein to provide tissue-specific regulation. Ouabain and rubidium are often used to measure the activity of these proteins. Cardiac glycosides like digitalis inhibit this structure, which in turn inhibits NCX, creating increased calcium stores for more powerful heart contraction. This protein was discovered by Jens Christian Skou and has (*) high affinity for certain ions before it is phosphorylated, but releases them afterwards. This transmembrane protein dephosphorylates an ATP to move three ions out of the cell and two ions in against their concentration gradients. For 10 points, name this active transporter which maintains resting cell potential by moving Na+ and K+.
tossups.answer: sodium-potassium pump [or Na+/K+ pump before mention]

tossups.question: A legendary wall built by Alexander the Great from this resource gave its name to passes at Derbent and Samarkand. The Chinese may have imported technology from the Scythians to create a “sponge” version of this resource in a “bloomery.” People with names referencing this substance include the last Yuan emperor, Toghon Temür, and Tamerlane. This was the alphabetically earlier good debated in “discourses” involving Huo Guang and Sang Hongyang. Emperor Wudi created a monopoly on (*) salt as well as this substance. An inscription praising Chandragupta II adorns a pillar made out of this resource in Delhi, which has resisted corrosion for over 1500 years. The Chinese were the first to produce this substance in its “cast” form. For 10 points, name this metal which used to be extracted from meteorites and names the “age” that preceded the Bronze Age.
tossups.answer: iron [or cast iron, wrought iron; Fe; ferrum]

tossups.question: Jonathan Lear analyzed the “knowingness” of one of this author’s characters and claimed he presents an either/or between submitting to reason or religion. Being killed by someone who is already dead is the prophesied fate of one of this playwright’s protagonists, who orders Hyllus to marry Iole on his deathbed. This author wrote about the death of (*) Hercules in Women of Trachis, and he wrote about a snakebitten archer in Philoctetes. One of his characters states that the gods alone never die, but Time destroys all other things; Theseus and Creon later fight over that character’s grave. This writer’s line “Call no man happy until he is dead” occurs in a play in which the title character vows to find a criminal who turns out to be himself. He then blinds himself since he killed his father and married his mother. For 10 points, name this playwright of the Oedipus trilogy.

In a form of this religious tradition, a leader was prophesized to ride a lion with a seven-headed dragon in its jaws as a signal of world salvation, but the leader mostly engendered mass apostasy. This tradition uses the spine to represent a balance of justice and mercy, which it calls the offspring of wisdom and understanding and the bridegroom of the divine presence. A sect of this religious tradition that ended in apostasy was the Polish Frankists. Its two original major schools were that of the (*) Heavenly Chambers and the Divine Chariot. Worship of this religious tradition was co-opted by Christian mystics like Pico della Mirandola during the early Renaissance in Italy. This tradition lists Din and Hesed among ten “emanations” called the Sefirot. For 10 points, give the general name for this tradition whose most essential work is the Zohar, described as Jewish mysticism.
tossups.answer: Kabbalah [prompt on “Jewish mysticism” or “Judaism” before mention; accept “Sabbatean” or “Donmeh” and generously prompt on “Islamic Judaism” or “crypto-Judaism” until “Polish”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Kabbalah [prompt on “Jewish mysticism”prompt on “Judaism” before mention; accept “Sabbatean” or “Donmeh” and generously prompt on “Islamic Judaism” or “crypto-Judaism” until “Polish”]

tossups.question: John Paul Stevens broke from the Supreme Court’s liberal bloc to dissent in a case from this state whose verdict was confirmed a year later in United States v. Eichman. This state’s decision to sell $10 million in US government bonds after joining the Confederacy led to an 1869 Supreme Court ruling that declared secession unconstitutional. Justice Scalia wrote “the Court has taken sides in the Culture War” in his dissent to a case from it in which the plaintiffs were represented by (*) LAMBDA Legal. A man arrested at a Republican National Convention here overturned its anti-flag burning law in the case [this state] v. Johnson. A case named for this state overturned the Court’s earlier decision in Bowers v. Hardwick. For 10 points, name this state whose anti-sodomy laws were struck down in a 2003 Supreme Court case brought by John Lawrence after an arrest near Houston.

This technique is used to distinguish bridging and non-bridging ligands in metal carbonyl complexes and bent versus linear ligands in nitrosyl complexes. The DRIFTS version of this technique requires no sample preparation. Substitutions in a nickel carbonyl complex, in conjunction with this technique, are used to find a ligand’s Tolman electronic parameter. A zinc selenide crystal is used in the total internal reflection variant of this technique; more commonly, samples are smeared on (*) potassium bromide salt plates. The fingerprint region lies between 500 and 1500 wavenumbers in the output of this technique, which only detects vibrational modes that change the dipole moment. Carbonyls show up around 1700 wavenumbers in this technique. For 10 points, name this form of spectroscopy that uses wavelengths longer than visible light.

One priest of this god, Pra’em-hab, complained about being taxed more than other gods’ priests. Seventy-two conspirators including Queen Aso helped this god, whose army was destroyed when his enemy turned into a giant disk and blinded them. In one myth, this god is kept chained in the Great Bear by Taweret; this god ripped himself from his mother’s womb since he was too impatient to be born normally. This god was associated with the carp, which ate the (*) penis of a man he had ripped apart. This god of foreigners was tricked into eating lettuce with some semen on it, as well as losing a boat race because he made a boat of stone which sank. This husband of Nephythys (Nef-this) fought Apep on Ra’s boat and battled with Horus, who was trying to avenge his father. For 10 points, name this god of storms who killed his brother Osiris.

This artist depicted a woman in a pink and black lace wrap in front of an eerily craggy landscape in his portrait of Lady Alston. This artist’s most famous work was possibly painted to spite a rival who said that pictures should have mostly warm colors. This artist painted two girls in gold and silver in The Painter’s Daughters Chasing a Butterfly, and in another work, he depicted a pensive girl with short hair watching some pigs drink milk. A blank patch is left in the lap of one of this painter’s subjects, who wears a blue dress and sits under a (*) tree next to her rifle-holding husband in a work displaying their vast tracts of land. Another of this artist’s portraits is displayed with Thomas Lawrence’s “Pinkie” and probably shows Jonathan Buttall. For 10 points, name this rival of Joshua Reynolds, an English painter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrews and The Blue Boy.

This composer chose to remove the Waldmarchen first part in one of his works possibly due to the death of his brother; that cantata was based on a Brothers Grimm tale about a bone flute that would sing human words when it was played. Although he is not Elgar, Janet Baker and Sir John Barbirolli created a well-received recording of this man’s lieders, and this man included “Um Mitternacht” and “Liebst du um Schönheit” in a song collection based on poems by (*) Friedrich Ruckert. In a song by this person titled “Wenn dein Mütterlein,” pizzicato strings imitate the footstep of a child entering with her mother; that song is part of his Kindertotenlieder. For 10 points, name this German composer who frequently employed Des Knaben Wunderhorn as a setting for many of his songs and symphonic works such as Resurrection Symphony.

The dancer slowly proceeds from a reclining to a standing position in Frederick Ashton’s work, Five Brahms Waltzes in the Manner of [this choreographer]. This dancer was painted by Abraham Walkowitz and choreographed Marche Funebre in response to her mother’s death. Anna Denzler and Elizabeth Milker were two of this woman’s six proteges named after her. This dancer praised “the highest intelligence in the freest body” in her speech “The Dance of the Future” and expressed her controversial (*) Communist views in a work set to Scriabin music, The Revolutionary. In her Dionysion school, this dancer emphasized natural, wave-like movement. This ancient-Greek inspired dancer often worked in tunics and bare feet. For 10 points, name this modern dancer who died when one of her trademark long scarves got caught under a car.

A poem in this collection describes a time in which “cold stars heave up” and “the night fastens to all timetables.” That poem’s addressee is asked “Who writes your name in letters of smoke?” and “play[s] with the light of the universe.” A poem in this collection states “Like a jar you housed the infinite tenderness” and describes the addressee’s foreign presence when she is “thinking, tangling shadows.” This collection’s narrator describes himself as “drunk with pines” in the ocean, and it begins by describing (*) “white hills, white thighs” in “Body of a Woman.” The line “Love is so short, forgetting is so long” appears in its poem “Tonight I can write the saddest lines.” This collection’s finale laments “It is the hour of departure” and repeats “In you everything sank!” For 10 points, name this collection of 21 romantic poems with a sad conclusion by Pablo Neruda.
tossups.answer: Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair [or Veinte poemas de amor y una canción desesperada]
tossups.answer_formatted: Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair [or Veinte poemas de amor y una canción desesperada]
acceptable: Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair
Veinte poemas de amor y una canción desesperada

tossups.question: The power of these organizations was diminished by the Hartz IV plan, which was part of the Agenda 2010. The philosophy of one of these organizations was derived from the essay “Theses on Hope and Hopelessness,” and leaders of it were given “one-way passports” to leave their home country. These organizations and political parties joined in a “sacred bond” to support World War I in France. They negotiated the never implemented (*) Grenelle Agreements. The most influential one of them in Germany is IG Metall, while the largest in France is the CGT. One of these organizations was the most prominent negotiator at the Round Table Talks, which led to the resignation of General Jaruzelski. One of them agitated at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk and was led by Lech Walesa. For 10 points, name these organizations that included Poland’s Solidarity.
tossups.answer: unions [accept labor unions and trade unions]

tossups.question: An electron gas where kT is much less than the Fermi energy is described using this term. Using a form of perturbation theory described by this term requires finding a Hermitian operator that commutes with both the perturbed and unperturbed Hamiltonians. The weak-field (*) Zeeman effect gives an energy correction proportional to the Bohr magneton times the Landé g-factor, splitting states with this property. A quantity described by this term is proportional to the electron density to the five-thirds power; that pressure described by this term prevents white dwarves from collapsing under their own gravity. For 10 points, give this term which describes states of a quantum system with the same energy.

Two Answers Required. In the chapter "Going [this country]," Steve Pincus argues that this country's economic model set the stage for the "First Modern Revolution" in this other country. A surprise attack by one of these countries on the other captured Sheerness despite a chain called the Gillingham Line. Late in life, Prince Rupert of the Rhine participated in a battle between them in the Battle of Lowestoft. The Battle of Scheveningen between them resulted in the death of Maarten Tromp. The naval (*) Four Days’ Battle occurred between these countries. A ruler of one of them invaded the other on the ship Brill after being invited by nobles called the “Immortal Seven.” A prince from one of these countries became ruler of the other by winning the Battle of the Boyne. For 10 points, William of Orange from one of these countries became king of this other country in the Glorious Revolution.
tossups.answer: England and Dutch Republic [accept Republic of the Seven United Netherlands or Nederland or Holland for “Dutch”; accept Great Britain or United Kingdom for “England”]
tossups.answer_formatted: England and Dutch Republic [accept Republic of the Seven United Netherlands or Nederland or Holland for “Dutch”; accept Great Britain or United Kingdom for “England”]
acceptable: Republic of the Seven United Netherlands

tossups.question: The image of a human skull displayed inside a busted TV set concludes an essay about this neighborhood that begins with a description of Leonard Deadwyler’s death. Thomas Pynchon’s “Journey Into The Mind Of [this neighborhood]” discusses how an Italian immigrant used scrap steel, broken soda bottles, and other found objects to construct one of its landmarks. Football player Jim Brown helped negotiate a 1992 ceasefire agreement between the (*) Bloods and the Crips in this neighborhood. This neighborhood is the site of some namesake “towers” built by Simon Rodia. Police chief Bill Parker employed military-style tactics during a disturbance in this neighborhood instigated by the arrest of Marquette Frye. For 10 points, name this predominantly African-American neighborhood in Los Angeles, the namesake of a 1965 race riot.
tossups.answer: Watts [or “A Journey Into The Mind of Watts”; prompt on “Los Angeles” or “South Los Angeles”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Watts [or “A Journey Into The Mind of Watts”; prompt on “Los Angeles” or “South Los Angeles”]
acceptable: “A Journey Into The Mind of Watts”

tossups.question: Attractive and repulsive forces are used to neatly draw these things in the Fruchterman-Reingold algorithm. Register allocation during compilation is modeled as a problem which often uses contraction on these things. A conjecture about that problem by Erdos, Faber, and Lovasz proposes that k (*) colors can color the union of k of these things. Kosaraju’s algorithm is used to find strongly-connected components in these structures, which can be topologically sorted if they are “DAGs.” These objects are usually represented with an adjacency list or matrix, and breadth-first search and depth-first search can be used to traverse these directed or undirected structures. For 10 points, name these structures consisting of nodes and edges.

This author created the University College of Abertawe professor Athro Haines, who wrote a book on “medieval Cwmrhydyceirw” that the protagonist pretends to have heard of to impress his boss. Philip Larkin and this author created a game where they would replace words in literary quotes with obscenities, like “I have gathered up six slender basketfuls OF HORSEPISS.” The “shadowy Argentinian outfit” for which this author wrote a Graham Greene monograph inspired his character of Dr. L. S. Caton, who plagiarizes an article on (*) medieval shipbuilding. The ghost of Dr. Underhill conjures a being made of twigs to haunt the title inn of a novel by this author. This author of The Green Man wrote a novel in which a lecture on “Merrie England’ is drunkenly delivered by Professor Dixon. For 10 points, name this author of Lucky Jim.

The English translation of one of this author’s works was done by William Boyce Gibson, who used “sense” and “conceptual significance” for “Sinn” and “Bedeutung.” That work discusses the “principle of all principles,” the “natural standpoint,” and the noesis and noema. This philosopher identified morphology of meanings, logic of consequence, and metalogic as three increasingly abstract strata of logic. This philosopher wrote that he wanted to found “a science covering a new field of experience, exclusively its own, that of (*) Transcendental Subjectivity.” He identified a kind of “reduction” that consists of pure consciousness of the Being of some intentional object, and argued that logicians had failed to pay attention to the role of subjective consciousness. For 10 points, name this author of Cartesian Meditations and Logical Investigations who founded phenomenology.

bonuses.leadin: This person was married to Marcus Claudius Marcellus, who tragically died at the age of 19. For 10 points each:
answers: Julia the Elder [or Julia daughter of Augustus; do not accept or prompt on “Julia the Younger”]
parts: Name this person had an affair with Sempronius Gracchus. This person’s alleged promiscuity undermined her father’s legislation against adultery, so she was exiled to Pandateria and not allowed to have male visitors.

The Emperor Augustus was much kinder to this third wife of his than to his daughter, Julia. This mother of Tiberius was a key advisor to Augustus despite likely false claims she poisoned him with a fig.
Augustus did not get along super well with this queen and last real ruler of Ptolemaic Egypt, who lost the Battle of Actium along with her lover, Marc Antony.
answers_formatted: Julia the Elder [or Julia daughter of Augustus; do not accept or prompt on "“Julia the Younger”"]

bonuses.leadin: This person was married to Marcus Claudius Marcellus, who tragically died at the age of 19. For 10 points each:
answers: Julia the Elder [or Julia daughter of Augustus; do not accept or prompt on “Julia the Younger”]
parts: Name this person had an affair with Sempronius Gracchus. This person’s alleged promiscuity undermined her father’s legislation against adultery, so she was exiled to Pandateria and not allowed to have male visitors.

The Emperor Augustus was much kinder to this third wife of his than to his daughter, Julia. This mother of Tiberius was a key advisor to Augustus despite likely false claims she poisoned him with a fig.
Augustus did not get along super well with this queen and last real ruler of Ptolemaic Egypt, who lost the Battle of Actium along with her lover, Marc Antony.
answers_formatted: Julia the Elder [or Julia daughter of Augustus; do not accept or prompt on "“Julia the Younger”"]

bonuses.leadin: In a Philip K. Dick story, agents attempt to undermine a totalitarian society controlled by a super-bland reality TV star by having him say he likes this artist instead of Thomas Kinkade. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist of The Ship of Fools who achieved true PKD levels of trippiness by painting stuff like some giant ears with a knife, a Tree Man, and a pig in a nun’s wimple in Hell in The Garden of Earthly Delights.
The outer portion of The Garden of Earthly Delights triptych shows the world as a watery orb and is painted in this black-and-white style, usually intended to imitate sculpture.

This Bosch painting is the right panel of a triptych with The Ship of Fools and Allegory of Gluttony and Lust. It shows an emaciated man lying in bed behind his formerly healthy, rich self while demons creep in at all sides.

bonuses.leadin: On his way to Cremona, this character is so stressed by the idea of losing his lecture notes that he fails to realize that he’s boarded the wrong train. For 10 points each:
answers: Timofey Pavlovich Pnin [accept either underlined part]
parts: Name this professor at Waindell College who tries to reconnect with his son, Victor. In a rare moment of vulnerability, he tearfully cries, “I haf nothing! Nothing!”
Pnin appears in an eponymous novel by this Russian, who created the pedophile Humbert Humbert in Lolita.

Pnin appears in this other Nabokov novel as a professor at Wordsmith University. This novel is presented as a 999-line poem written by a fictional author, with a lengthy forward and commentary also by a fictional author.

bonuses.leadin: Harold Demsetz’s “Towards a Theory of Property Rights” theorizes that in the absence of these entities, the exchange of property results in an efficient outcome. For 10 points each:
answers: The University of Chicago [or UChicago; or U of C]
internalize the externalities [accept word forms for both words; accept phrase variations like the externalities are internalized; prompt on “internalize” alone with “internalize what?”]
parts: Name these things whose absence is also felt in the Coase Theorem. Coase himself later said his theorem didn’t apply in the real world because you can’t describe a world without these.

The Coase Theorem made its first appearance in “The Problem of Social Cost,” an extremely highly cited article in this university’s law review. This university’s namesake school of economics included Milton Friedman.

This situation occurs when external costs borne by a third party are shifted back to the party that created them. Coase argued that low transaction costs make outside intervention to accomplish this unnecessary.
answers_formatted: The University of Chicago [or UChicago; or U of C]
internalize the externalities [accept word forms for both words; accept phrase variations like the externalities are internalized; prompt on “internalize” alone with “internalize what?”]
acceptable: phrase variations like the externalities are internalized

bonuses.leadin: Members of one religious group in this country self-immolated in 2005 to protest their persecution. For 10 points each:
parts: The aforementioned agricultural sect of Buddhism, whose devotees worship at brown cloth altars, originated in this country.
This ethnic group lives in Vietnam, amongst other southeast Asian countries. They have an animistic belief system and look to shamans called txiv neeb (tse neng) to heal various ailments.
Missionaries of this religion created a system for writing Vietnamese in Latin. President Diem was an unpopular practitioner of this religion.

bonuses.leadin: Members of this domain are infected by pleolipoviridae and spiraviridae, and unusually have ether-linked lipids in their membranes. For 10 points each:
answers: 16S rRNA [prompt on RNA, ribosomal RNA, or rRNA]
parts: Name this third domain, which consists of single-celled organisms that often live in extreme environments.
Unlike the other two domains, archaea use a formylated derivative of this amino acid. This amino acid is encoded by the start codon, and removing its terminal methyl group gives homocysteine.
Carl Woese organized life into 3 domains by sequencing this sub-component of the small ribosomal subunit. Its 3’ end contains the anti-Shine-Dalgarno sequence.

bonuses.leadin: The Long Hot Summer of 1967 saw race riots flare up across the United States. For 10 points each:
answers: Kerner Commission [also accept National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders]
parts: Twenty-three civilians were killed in the 12th Street Riot in this city. The riot most likely contributed to the 20th century population decline of this Motor City, which continues to the present day.

This commission was established due to the race riots of 1967 and was named after the Illinois governor who chaired it. It sought to establish the cause of the riots and recommend future actions reducing racial tensions.

This Governor of Maryland lost the support of black voters due to his attempt to prosecute SNCC Chairman H. Rap Brown after 1967 riots in Cambridge. He dubbed opponents “hopeless, hysterical hypochondriacs of history.”
answers_formatted: Kerner Commission [also accept National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders]

bonuses.leadin: Randell Jarrell fictionalized this novelist as Gertrude Johnson in his satire Pictures from an Institution. For 10 points each:
answers: Mary McCarthy (the mentioned novel is The Group)
hell [or obvious synonyms; prompt on the afterlife, the underworld, hereafter, etc]
parts: Name this author, wrote about the disconnected life of Meg Sargent in The Company She Keeps. A novel by this author follows eight female friends at Vassar, including Kay Strong and Helena Davison.

About this author, Mary McCarthy once quipped that “Every word she writes is a lie, including ‘and’ and ‘the.’” Mary Tilford’s lies bring down a girl’s school in this author’s play The Children’s Hour.
In Nora Ephron’s play Imaginary Friends, Hellman and McCarthy recall their feud after meeting in this place. Garcin declares that this place is “other people” in Jean-Paul Sartre’s No Exit.
answers_formatted: hell [or obvious synonyms; prompt on the afterlife, the underworld, hereafter, etc]
metadata: the mentioned novel is The Group

bonuses.leadin: The Naive Bayes algorithm can be used to perform this task. For 10 points each:
answers: classification (do not accept or prompt on clustering)
diagonal [prompt on description like “all the non-diagonal elements are zero”]
parts: Name this task in machine learning which predicts labels for new inputs given a set of already-labeled data points.
One interpretation of the Naive Bayes algorithm is that it attempts to fit a distribution to each class where the covariance matrix of the features has this property.

Another interpretation of Naive Bayes is that it assumes that all the features of the data have this relationship. In statistics, two events have this relationship if the outcome of one does not affect the other.
answers_formatted: diagonal [prompt on description like “all the non-diagonal elements are zero”]
promptable: description like “all the non-diagonal elements are zero”
metadata: do not accept or prompt on clustering

bonuses.leadin: Even if you’re not Audrey Hepburn or Gregory Peck, you can take a Roman holiday. For 10 points each:
parts: For this ancient Roman holiday which took place in May, the head of the household got up at midnight and walked around the house barefoot throwing black beans to expel ghosts.
On Lemuria, these women would prepare flour cake. These priestesses of the goddess of the hearth were sworn to celibacy and were responsible for keeping a sacred fire from going out.

This two-word Latin phrase was used to celebrate its namesake holiday, on which slaves and masters switched places and gambling was permitted. The emperor yelled this exclamation to the crowd after the opening ceremony.

bonuses.leadin: Several years after his controversial paper with Elisabeth Landes, Richard Posner has claimed strenuously that he was not advocating for a market in this commodity. For 10 points each:
answers: babies [or equivalents like infants or children]
parts: Name this commodity that Posner and Landes argue has excess demand due to the large number of infertile couples. They argue that restrictions on adoption should be eased to promote efficiency in this commodity.
In “The Ethical Limitations of the Market,” this University of Michigan philosopher argues that economic goods have certain qualities that make them suitable for markets.
Drawing from Mauss and Sahlins, Anderson argues that this type of exchange differs from market exchange because it bonds donor and recipient and allows for delays in reciprocity.

bonuses.leadin: This person was nicknamed the “Silver Fox” for his white hair and reputation for craftiness. For 10 points each:
answers: Orange Revolution [or Pomaranchev revolyutsiya; or 2004 Ukrainian Revolution; 2005 Ukrainian Revolution]
parts: Name this Soviet Foreign Minister from 1985 to 1991. This person’s negotiations with U.S. counterpart James Baker after the fall of the Berlin Wall helped lead to the reunification of Germany in the Two Plus Four Agreement.

Shevardnadze is better known as the president of this country from 1995 to 2003, when he was deposed in the peaceful Rose Revolution. This country fought Russia over its border regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia.

This event took place a year after the Rose Revolution and resulted from voter fraud in an election to succeed Leonid Kuchma. Viktor Yushchenko won the re-run election that occurred as a result of it.
answers_formatted: Orange Revolution [or Pomaranchev revolyutsiya; or 2004 Ukrainian Revolution; 2005 Ukrainian Revolution]

bonuses.leadin: Fourier series are super useful. For 10 points each:
answers: finite support or are zero outside some interval or anything equivalent
parts: Joseph Fourier introduced them while attempting to solve this equation, which states that the time derivative of u is proportional to the Laplacian of u.
The basic idea behind Fourier series is to express arbitrary functions as a sums of these two kinds of basic trigonometric functions, whose squares sum to one.
In signal processing, the Shannon-Nyquist theorem applies to signals whose Fourier transforms have this property, which means that the frequencies of the original function are bounded.
answers_formatted: finite support or are zero outside some interval or anything equivalent
acceptable: finite support or are zero outside some interval or anything equivalent

bonuses.leadin: One of these actions is performed at a shrine where a pine and palm tree grow out of the same trunk. For 10 points each:
answers: love suicides [accept any manner of self-caused death, such as poisoning oneself, drowning oneself, stabbing oneself, etc]
The Uprooted Pine [or Nebiki no Kadomatsu]
parts: Name this action performed by the lovers Jihei and Koharu at Amijima and Tokubei and Ohatsu at Sonezaki in namesake plays. Romeo and Juliet commit this act at the end of a Shakespeare play.
The Love Suicides at Sonezaki and The Love Suicides at Amijima were written by this bunraku and kabuki dramatist. He also fictionalized historical events in The Battles of Coxinga.
In this other Chikamatsu play, the prostitute Azuma is in love with Yojibei, who cannot marry her due to his wife Okiku. All ends happily when Yohei is able to outbid Hikosuke for Azuma’s freedom.
answers_formatted: love suicides [accept any manner of self-caused death, such as poisoning oneself, drowning oneself, stabbing oneself, etc]
acceptable: any manner of self-caused death, such as poisoning oneself, drowning oneself, stabbing oneself, etc

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some celebrity guest stars from Bojack Horseman:
parts: A flashback to Diane’s time as a barista shows that Mr. Peanutbutter’s second wife was this American actress, who broke up with Mr. Peanutbutter to date Justin Timberlake.

In the first season, Bojack hires this person to ruin Diane’s marriage by enacting a bank robbery. This American actress won multiple Emmys thanks to her roles as Mags Bennett in Justified and as Claudia in The Americans.
In the final segment of Mr. Peanutbutter’s game show, Bojack confuses the similarly-featured Elijah Wood with this actor who plays the titular wizard in the Harry Potter series.

bonuses.leadin: Michelle Bachelet is one of the few remaining leaders part of a movement known by this color. For 10 points each:
answers: pink [pink tide; pink map; rose-coloured map; mapa cor de rosa]
parts: Give this color that names a “tide” of leftist Latin American leaders who rejected the Washington Consensus in the 1990s. A Portuguese map of this color laid out their claims to the areas of Africa from Angola to Mozambique.
These people lived in part of the land claimed by the Pink Map. These people created the Kingdom of Mutapa, and they built a “Conical Tower” in their greatest city.
The Shona people likely conducted substantial trade with a region of Africa known as the “[this language] coast.” This Bantu language has tons of speakers in Tanzania and Kenya.
answers_formatted: pink [pink tide; pink map; rose-coloured map; mapa cor de rosa]

bonuses.leadin: Musette in D Major from this collection is frequently anthologized in beginner’s piano books. For 10 points each:
answers: Notebooks for Anna Magdalena Bach [prompt on less specific answers, like Notebooks for J.S. Bach’s Wife]
Minuet in G major [or BWV Anh. 114]
parts: Name these collections of works which include aria “Bist du Bei Mir” and the first five of the composer’s “French” suites.

Perhaps the most famous work in the notebooks for Anna Magdalena is this G major piece for piano that is usually attributed to Christian Petzold. The melody of the piece starts like (read slowly) D-G-A-B-C D-G-G.
Bach included Les Bergeries by this French composer of Les Barricades Mystérieuses in the second notebook.
answers_formatted: Notebooks for Anna Magdalena Bach [prompt on less specific answers, like Notebooks for J.S. Bach’s Wife]
promptable: less specific answers, like Notebooks for J.S. Bach’s Wife

bonuses.leadin: Many authors have created new versions of the Arthurian Fisher King. For 10 points each:
parts: This author set the legend on a cruise ship, with the Fisher King as the wounded veteran Saul Henchman. He is also known for telling the story of Nick Jenkins in a twelve-book series including A Question of Upbringing.

This writer wrote about literary professor’s Persse McGarrigle’s attempt to woo Angelica Pabst, the daughter of the archly-named Arthur Kingfisher in Small World, featuring the professors Philip Swallow and Morris Zapp.

This author wrote about Wart and the backwards-living Merlin in The Sword and the Stone, before dealing more seriously with the Grail legend in The Ill-Made Knight, both parts of The Once and Future King.

bonuses.leadin: One agent for performing this task is the piano-stool complex MMT. For 10 points each:
answers: antiknock agents [or any variation of “preventing knocking”]
oxygen evolution [accept oxygen-evolving complex or OEC]
parts: Name this function also carried out by lead tetra-acetate, ferrocene, and iron pentacarbonyl. These gasoline additives prevent a phenomenon in which pockets of air/fuel mixtures explode independent of the combustion wave.

The center of MMT contains an atom of this element. A compound formed between potassium and an anion containing this element in its +7 oxidation state turns a deep purple color when dissolved in water.
Four manganese atoms are found in an complex that carries out this reaction in photosystem II. Water is split in this reaction, which turns the dye DCIP colorless.

bonuses.leadin: This theorist claimed that the human drive to create art sprang from our need to protect the physical body from death. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this influential film critic who posited the “mummy complex” in “The Ontology of the Photographic Image,” an essay from his collection What is Cinema? Truffaut wrote for this man’s magazine, Cahiers du Cinema.

Under Bazin’s tutelage, Truffaut and the other Cahiers writers came up with this film theory concept, in which the director is recognized as the primary author of a film text. Its shares its name with the French word for “author.”

To demonstrate auteur theory, the editors of Cahiers du Cinema wrote an analysis of this director’s film Young Mr. Lincoln. This director of The Grapes of Wrath also made a film that begins and ends with shots of John Wayne’s character framed in a cabin’s doorway.
